title: Allah says Muslims should walk humbly and deal with the 'foolish' politely (Quran 25.63)? Is Allah teaching Muslims to present an appearance of humility while internally thinking themselves to be superior? - Quora

response.answer_text: (25:63) The true servants of the Merciful One are those who walk on the earth gently and when the foolish ones address them, they simply say: "Peace to you". That is, though all human beings are by birth the servants of the Merciful before Whom you have been invited to prostrate yourselves, and which you disdain, his true servants are those who adopt the way of His obedience consciously and develop such desirable characteristics. Then the natural consequences of the prostration are those found in the lives of the believers and the evil results of rejecting the invitation, those found in your lives. Here attention is being drawn to the two patterns of character and life. First of those who had accepted the message of the Prophet (peace be upon him) and were following it, and the second of those who persisted in the ways of ignorance. Here only the prominent characteristics of the true believers have been cited, and for contrast, the characteristics of the disbelievers have been left to every discerning eye and mind which could see them all around in the society and make its own decision. That is; they do not walk haughtily and arrogantly like the tyrants and mischief-makers, but their gait is of a gentle, right thinking and good natured person. Walking humbly does not mean walking like a weak or sick person, nor does it imply the gait of a hypocrite who walks ostentatiously to show humility or fear of God. According to traditions, the Prophet (peace be upon him) himself used to walk with firm, quick steps. One day Caliph Umar saw a young man walking slowly like a weak, sick person, and asked him: Are you ill? When the man replied in the negative, the Caliph raised his whip, rebuked him and told him to walk like a healthy man. This shows that the humble gait is the natural gait of a noble and gentle person and not a gait which shows weakness and undue humility. In this connection, the first characteristic of the true servants of Allah to which attention has been drawn, is their gait. This is because the gait indicates the character of an individual. If a man walks in a humble and dignified way, as opposed to a haughty, vain and proud manner, it shows that he is a noble and gentle person. Thus the different gaits of different types of people show what sort of characters they possess. The verse means to imply that the true servants of the Merciful can be easily recognized by their gait among the people. Their attitude of Allah’s worship and obedience has changed them so thoroughly that it can be seen at first sight from their gate that they are noble, humble and good natured people, who cannot be expected to indulge in any mischief. For further explanation, . “the ignorant people”: Rude and insolent people and not uneducated and illiterate ones. The true servants of the Merciful do not believe in vengeance, even though they may have to deal with the ignorant people who behave rudely and insolently towards them. If they happen to come across such people, they wish them peace and turn away. The same thing has been expressed in (Q28:55), thus: And when they hear something vain and absurd they turn away from it, saying, our deeds are for us and your deeds are for you, peace be to you, we have nothing to do with the ignorant.

The verse you mentioned: it says if someone mocks you then say “peace” and leave. For, [true] servants of the Most Gracious are [only] they who walk gently on earth, and who, whenever the “jahils" address them, reply with [words of] peace. (Quran 25:63) Firstly, the more accurate translation of the word in this context is probably “unaware” or “ignorant”, not fool. And is it not common sense that if A mocks B, A is the arrogant one? God will requite them for their mockery, and will leave them for a while in their overweening arrogance, blindly stumbling to and fro: (Quran, 2:15) Secondly, There are two terms “tolerance” and “acceptance” and there are difference between in these two. Tolerance: “I know I am better than you, but still I am accepting you.”Acceptance: “I accept that every one will not believe the way I believe”.The amount of commandment in the Quran for the believers to accept the disbelief and “let go” is numerous. VERILY, you cannot not guide aright everyone whom you love: but it is God who guides him that wills [to be guided] and He is fully aware of all who would let themselves be guided. (Quran 28:56) "The truth [has now come] from your Sustainer: Let, then, him who wills, believe in it, and let him who wills, reject it," (Quran 18:29) Thirdly, the command to behave well with them is because, it may change them eventually. NOT because “we consider ourselves better”. Requite evil with what is better and lo, he who is your enemy now will become as if your intimate friend. (41:34) Forthly, Muslims are prohibited to be double faced (thinking something inwardly, but doing something else outwardly). So answer to your question is “No”! Our inside and outside should be same! O YOU who have attained to faith! Why do you say one thing and do another? Most loathsome is it in the sight of God that you say what you do not do! (Quran 61:2–3) Lastly, we cannot ascribe purity to ourselves. We hold God as the ultimate judge, only he can know what has someone earned. do not, then, consider your­selves pure - [for] He knows best as to who is conscious of Him (53:32) I can never know that who will ultimately have a better place than me in the paradise (only God knows). So I have no way to look down to other. let not a people ridicule [another] people; perhaps they may be better than them; nor let women ridicule [other] women; perhaps they may be better than them. (49:11)

While you do want to avoid the fools (7:199), cultivating tolerance and enjoining justice are just as important. Pride and arrogance are not the same thing. Pride is “I’m the best version of myself I can be, I’m not perfect, and I strive to be better as each day passes”. Arrogance is, “I’m better than you.”. There are some matters/situations and acts in which we don’t just think we are better, we know we are better, but it’s not enough to revel in this awareness if you aren’t helping others also to be better by spreading your knowledge. For instance, if we as Muslims teach others the salah sequence, it is up to them to incorporate it into their lives. We can provide them with tutorials and books and help them understand the reasons both physical and spiritual for why we perform this. Whether it be a matter of maturity, peer pressure, or familial pressure to stay in their current religion, it is not our job to judge, but rather perceive and at the very least, be a good friend as a Muslim that they can rely upon. If they turn away from this wisdom, it’s not your job to be their babysitter. You’re not guardian over them, and if they chastise you for being Muslim, we aren’t the ones with the arrogance problem; they are. They are too good to bring their face toward the Earth that gives them life and submit to Allah. So just be yourself, and let the haters hate.

How do you draw the conclusion of thinking oneself to be superior just because one conducts oneself with humility and politeness? We read the entirety of the Qur'aan, or should; if you did, you would read that arrogance and concluding oneself to be superior are qualities that are greatly disliked by Allaah. This does not give rise to your conclusion. It's not possible. There are always those who are better than oneself, and remembering that as well as the results of arrogance is important. Do not avert your face from people out of haughtiness and do not strut about arrogantly on the Earth. Allah does not love anyone who is vain or boastful. (Surah Luqman: 18) Truly, God knows all that they keep secret as well as all that they bring into the open -[and,] behold, He does not love those who are given to arrogance. (16:23)
